channel.title: jimgrisham tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from jimgrisham.

item.description: @schneierblog Must be a fertile target. MSPs based on CSPs based on poor software engineering practices using unsafe tools is not a stunning foundation for stability and security.

@JohnHBillings @EliNew18 @Viking95 @BretDevereaux The Roman Empire could also be a vastly different society from one century to the next. Perhaps time/fate caught up with them, or perhaps by the end they lost sight of some of the qualities that made them once so adaptable.
@EliNew18 @BretDevereaux Entropy and time eventually kills everything, whether one is talking about salmon, sequoias, or societies.

@Bradninchfellow @BretDevereaux If a place such as Lebanon magically became homogeneous, would all of its problems disappear? (I don’t actually know, of course) Diversity is often used as a target of blame when things are not going well with a society. Blame neighboring nations for ones intractable problems?
@dobrovecer11 @BretDevereaux As I understand (from thousands of kilometers away) they are more so than many nations, both ethnically and socially.

@IainBancarz @BurtWestermeier @BretDevereaux … and at the same time too large. If Malta instead had decided to leave the EU, they likely could have obtained better trade arrangements than the UK, because their economy is so much smaller; less of an economic threat/competitor.

@chumak_iryna @britinvan @KiarKini @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock Previous major societal collapses happened in a different world, though. Today, even peasants can receive near instantaneous news from the other side of the planet. Young people in isolated and poor places (i.e. Nepal) have more options than ever. Uncharted territory this is.

@chumak_iryna @KiarKini @britinvan @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock If Russia successfully breaks into pieces, the Basques might be inspired. Perhaps the Scots. Perhaps the Kurds. Andalusians. Balochs. Hmong. Palestinians. Rohingya. Uyghurs. Zulu. There will be an _enormous_ amount of elite pressure (worldwide) to prevent that idea spreading.

@chumak_iryna @KiarKini @britinvan @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock The collapse of the USSR was rather orderly compared to what _could_ happen to the Russian Federation, though. If the Russian economy collapses before the government does, perhaps the chaos following the fall of Rome might be a better precedent?

@chumak_iryna @britinvan @KiarKini @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock Choosing unity under fire is a testament to the wisdom of your countrymen. [All humans are cousins to one another, of course; in future centuries, I sincerely hope the concept of ‘they’ (‘war’, too) becomes an anachronism.] The world is with your people. Слава Україні!

@britinvan @chumak_iryna @KiarKini @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock … but perhaps in different combinations today, due to changed demographics (some forced) and better communication. Unanswered question for future historians: were smaller nations preferable to larger ones?
@FPdabo @KiarKini @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock All walls fall, eventually, despite the best efforts of the powerful. Even the most feared tyrants eventually die.

@chumak_iryna @britinvan @KiarKini @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock Putin has managed to keep Russia together so far; whoever comes next may not be able to manage such an ‘empire’. Will that ‘siloviki’ survive, and will they still get paid? If so, will someone pay their salary from their own pockets? Will the ‘siloviki’ splinter or stay united?

@chumak_iryna @britinvan @KiarKini @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock I agree. Outside of large cities, though, what if they didn’t _have_ to fight? If there is no one to fight against? If your town is a minority in a political subdivision, and the government collapses, then your town is a majority in your town. Perhaps your town becomes Monaco?

@chumak_iryna @britinvan @KiarKini @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock Parts of the USA would probably be better off as part of Canada, others as part of Mexico. Nation-states are such a recent contrivance, in terms of the history of human civilization. Their existence (and longevity) a thousand years from now may just be an interesting footnote.
